meaning_mnemonic: If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life," then to live one's life as 一人, means you are <vocabulary>living alone</vocabulary>.

恥 is a "disgrace." If you 知らず then you don't know something. In this case, you don't know disgrace, and a person who doesn't know disgrace is a <vocabulary>shameless person</vocabulary>, because they don't care what disgraces them and what doesn't.
An "examination hell" is the nickname given to the exams you have to take in Japan all at once. That's why this is <vocabulary>exam hell</vocabulary>.
When you're <kanji>boat</kanji> <kanji>drunk</kanji> you have <vocabulary>sea sickness</vocabulary>.

Remember how 鍋 means "<kanji>cooking pot</kanji>"? This is the suffix version of that, so it means ____<vocabulary>hotpot</vocabulary> or ____<vocabulary>stew</vocabulary>. 

Usually 〜鍋 will come after the name of the soup base or main ingredient, like 味噌鍋 (miso hotpot) or キムチ鍋 (kimchi stew).

If 払う is "to pay" or "to brush off," then the noun version is <vocabulary>payment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>brushing off</vocabulary>.

Usually 払い is tacked on the end of another word, like in カード払い (payment by credit card).

When it indicates a kind of brushing off or brushing away, it appears in words like 足払い (sweeping an opponent's legs in judo) or, more figuratively, せき払い (clearing one's throat).
An <kanji>oil</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is an <vocabulary>oil painting</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Sweet</kanji> <kanji>vinegar</kanji> is <vocabulary>sweet vinegar</vocabulary>. Them Japanese love their sweet things.

盛り上げる is "to heap up" - this has a similar idea, except now this is more like an excitement or swelling. As excitement heaps up in you, you are going <vocabulary>to get excited</vocabulary>. Note how 上がる is in here. This means something is happening to you (or something else), but you're not doing the action. When you get all sorts of excitement building up in you, you aren't really doing it, it's just happening on its own in reaction to something else.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>slow</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary> (or, if you're slow, you're probably <vocabulary>late</vocabulary>, too).

恥ずかしい is "embarrassing." This is the verb version. What happens when someone is embarrassed? They become shy and bashful. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be shy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be bashful</vocabulary>.
If 破る is "to tear" or "to rip," then this is <vocabulary>to get torn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get broken</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get ripped</vocabulary>.
A one's self (自己) introduction (紹介) is a <vocabulary>self introduction</vocabulary>.
A 紹介 is an introduction. So the verb version is <vocabulary>to introduce</vocabulary>.
Remember how a 年賀状 is a new year's card? This is another kind of card/letter, but this time it's for an introduction (紹介), making it a <vocabulary>letter of introduction</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>soup</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is what you use to refer to <vocabulary>soups</vocabulary>.
You know that 味噌 is "miso," and that 汁 is "soup." So, combine them together and you have <vocabulary>Miso Soup</vocabulary>.

If you're so <kanji>drunk</kanji> that you'll be <kanji>pay</kanji>ing for it later, it's safe to say you're a <vocabulary>drunk person</vocabulary>. You're way past being tipsy at this point, and you're definitely going to pay for it… with a hangover in the morning.
On the <kanji>second day</kanji>, you experience your <kanji>drunk</kanji>enness a different way... in the form of a <vocabulary>hangover</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>fueling</kanji> (給油) <kanji>place</kanji> is a place where you get things fueled. This can either be a <vocabulary>gas station</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>filling station</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hop</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hop</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to leap</vocabulary>. Basically anything that gets both feet off the ground via your own foot propulsion.

The <kanji>shining</kanji> <kanji>peace</kanji> time was a time known as the <vocabulary>Showa Era</vocabulary>. This can also refer to the <vocabulary>Showa Emperor</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>Showa</vocabulary> itself. Everything Showa is here.
A <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fisherman</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fishing boat</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>industry</kanji> is the <vocabulary>fishing industry</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fishery</vocabulary>.

To make <kanji>reparation</kanji>s is <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make up for</vocabulary> something. You're going <vocabulary>to atone for</vocabulary> your sins.

This word is mainly used when someone is taking responsibility for a mistake, a wrongdoing, or a loss by providing compensation or otherwise making things right.

My <kanji>dialect</kanji> has offended you? I will make <kanji>reparation</kanji> by giving you a <vocabulary>reimbursement</vocabulary> and some <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary>. I'm sorry my dialect was so bad you couldn't understand the speech. Here's your money back.
The <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> <kanji>facility</kanji> is the place you go to do your punishment tasks. It is a <vocabulary>jail</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>prison</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>death</kanji> <kanji>punish</kanji>ment is the <vocabulary>death penalty</vocabulary>.

You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." And someone who handles <kanji>punish</kanji>ment <kanji>matter</kanji>s is someone like a <vocabulary>police detective</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>detective</vocabulary>) trying to find and punish the bad guys.

刑事 isn't an official job title but a common way to refer to a police officer whose job is to investigate crimes and arrest criminals. Depending on the context, it can also refer to matters that fall under criminal law, like 刑事事件 (criminal case).
A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> is the time in which you are being punished in prison. This is your <vocabulary>prison term</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>penalty</kanji> is a <vocabulary>punishment</vocabulary>.

Until their <kanji>end</kanji>, <kanji>somebody</kanji> is being <kanji>punish</kanji>ed. If they're being punished until their end, they've probably been given a <vocabulary>life sentence</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>life imprisonment</vocabulary>.

The kanji is <kanji>recruit</kanji>, so this verb vocab version can also mean <vocabulary>to recruit</vocabulary>. However, its primary meaning is <vocabulary>to appeal for something</vocabulary>, like a job position or donations.

This verb can also be intransitive (oh my!) and mean <vocabulary>to grow stronger</vocabulary>, usually in reference to some sort of feelings or emotions. Make sure to check out the common word combinations for some example usages!

If you <kanji>recruit</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> you are trying to raise money. In other words, you're <vocabulary>fundraising</vocabulary>.

募金 originally just referred to the act of collecting <vocabulary>donations</vocabulary> for a cause, such as disaster relief, charity, or nonprofit activities. But nowadays, it can also mean the act of donating money for such a cause.

I want to <kanji>recruit</kanji> some people, so let's <kanji>gather</kanji> them up and do some <vocabulary>recruiting</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>solicitation</vocabulary> to get them.

募集 means looking for participants — whether that means job applicants, volunteers, contestants, or new club members. You'll often see it in official announcements and job ads.
I <kanji>respond</kanji> to your <kanji>recruit</kanji>ment with this <vocabulary>application</vocabulary> to try and join your group.

You learned that 執 means "<kanji>tenacious</kanji>," but it can also mean "carry out." The verb version here means <vocabulary>to take up</vocabulary>, like taking up a task or responsibility, or <vocabulary>to carry out</vocabulary>. 

執る is a formal word that means taking something in hand and carrying out an action. 筆を執る means "to take up the pen," for example, but also implies you're starting to write something meaningful. From this, 執る is also often used when someone takes charge of an important task or adopts a firm stance on something, like 指揮を執る (to take command).

You <kanji>tenacious</kanji>ly <kanji>wear</kanji> something. You have some kind of <vocabulary>attachment to</vocabulary> it. You can't let go. It's an <vocabulary>obsession</vocabulary>, after all, and you just can't stop <vocabulary>clinging to</vocabulary> it!

執着 usually refers to an unhealthy or excessive attachment to something. An obsession with money, dwelling on the past, or even persisting in your own narrow-minded beliefs — these are all kinds of 執着.

You learned that 執 means "tenacious," but it can also mean "<kanji>carry out</kanji>." So what do you carry out with a <kanji>writing brush</kanji>? You carry out <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary>! But not just any writing — this is <vocabulary>professional writing</vocabulary>, so you better get it right!

執筆 is a formal word for the act of writing, especially professional or important work like novels, magazine columns, news articles, or academic papers.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>baseball base</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> is a <vocabulary>base hit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>single</vocabulary> in baseball terms. A 二塁打 is a double, a 三塁打 is a triple, and a homerun is something you'll learn here on WaniKani at some point if you haven't already.

A <kanji>baseball base</kanji> <kanji>judge</kanji> is one who judges things on a baseball field. This is a <vocabulary>baseball umpire</vocabulary>, or more simply, an <vocabulary>umpire</vocabulary>.

The kanji is <kanji>crumble</kanji>, and this verb is for when you actively make or let something crumble, so it means <vocabulary>to break down</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to tear down</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to crumble</vocabulary>. It's transitive, so you're the one tearing stuff down. You can remember this because if you go around tearing down people's stuff, they'll probably sue (す).

崩す is for when you break down or loosen something that was solid or properly arranged. You can 崩す a sandcastle at the beach, your posture when you slouch, or even your health when you let yourself get worn down and sick. There are tons of ways to use this tricky word, so be sure check the context section for examples.
When something begins to <kanji>crumble</kanji> and <kanji>break</kanji>, it will certainly <vocabulary>collapse</vocabulary> at some point. It just can't hold up under the pressure.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>afflicted</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be afflicted with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to suffer from</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>afflicted</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who is <vocabulary>a patient</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>medical patient</vocabulary>. They are afflicted with some disease which is why they need medical attention.
Someone who is so <kanji>afflicted</kanji> that you have to <kanji>hurry</kanji> and help is an <vocabulary>emergency patient</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to return</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be returned</vocabulary>. This is when something does this on its own. You aren't doing the returning of something in this case.

Being in the <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>yonder</kanji> (the opposite side) means you are in one yonder and someone is in the other yonder, and you are coming towards each other. So this means <vocabulary>to be oncoming</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to come towards</vocabulary>.

If you're <kanji>anti</kanji> something and you <kanji>confront</kanji> the government about it, in some cases you are going <vocabulary>to rebel</vocabulary> against the government... that is, if you're crazy enough about it.
We are ready to <kanji>confront</kanji> <kanji>war</kanji>, if we have to. We are going to start the <vocabulary>resistance</vocabulary> against your regime, confront you, and even make war.
<kanji>Confront</kanji> your <kanji>body</kanji>? Sounds like it's something that's against bodies... perhaps, something that's <vocabulary>antibody</vocabulary>?

<kanji>Resist</kanji> and <kanji>confront</kanji> those who pressure or attack you. This is <vocabulary>to resist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to withstand</vocabulary>.

抵抗する means resisting an external force, whether physically or emotionally.

A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>resist</kanji> is something he <vocabulary>generally</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>usually</vocabulary> does... at least <vocabulary>in most cases</vocabulary>. He's usually a big resistor, that one.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Last Ten Days Of The Month

meaning_mnemonic: What are the <kanji>above</kanji> <kanji>ten days</kanji> of the month? They're the <vocabulary>first ten days of the month</vocabulary>, of course, or even just the <vocabulary>beginning of the month</vocabulary>.

meanings.meaning: First Ten Days Of The Month

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: First Ten Days Of The Month

meaning_mnemonic: These are the <kanji>below</kanji> <kanji>ten days</kanji> of the month. In other words, the <vocabulary>last ten days of the month</vocabulary>, or even just the <vocabulary>end of the month</vocabulary>.

meanings.meaning: Last Ten Days Of The Month

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>ten days</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle ten days of the month</vocabulary>. You could also call this the <vocabulary>middle of the month</vocabulary>.

meanings.meaning: Middle Ten Days Of The Month

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it contains some extra similar meanings as well, like a <vocabulary>bay</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inlet</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>machine</kanji> <kanji>gulf</kanji> isn't what you'd expect. In fact, looking at the reading will probably help the most first, since this word represents <vocabulary>Taiwan</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Explode</kanji> <kanji>departure</kanji> is when an explode departures from a certain point, causing an <vocabulary>explosion</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>explode</kanji> <kanji>bullet</kanji> is when an explode shoots out of something like a bullet, but much bigger, like from a <vocabulary>bomb</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>explode</kanji> with <kanji>laugh</kanji>s. Wow, what <vocabulary>explosive laughter</vocabulary>.

爆笑 means to <vocabulary>burst out laughing</vocabulary>, often loudly and uncontrollably. While it originally referred to group laughter, it can now also be used by and for individuals. You can even use it like <vocabulary>LOL</vocabulary> or LMAO in English: just stick it at the end of your Japanese messages to show you're really laughing it up.

If you <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>explode</kanji>, it means you're blowing up yourself, and probably taking others with you. This is a <vocabulary>suicide bomb</vocabulary>.

自爆 generally refers to <vocabulary>suicide bombing</vocabulary> in a military or terrorist context. Figuratively, it can also mean ruining one's own situation through careless actions, such as scoring an own goal in soccer.
An <kanji>explode</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is when someone attacks with exploding things, like bombs. This is a <vocabulary>bombing</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

弾 refers to <vocabulary>bullet</vocabulary>s and other projectiles, including artillery <vocabulary>shell</vocabulary>s and BB <vocabulary>pellet</vocabulary>s.

Weird that this kanji means <kanji>bullet</kanji> but the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone shooting a bullet. What does it do when it hits the right materials? It's going <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary>.
Back in the day, a <kanji>bullet</kanji> was a <kanji>circle</kanji> shape. So, this word is <vocabulary>bullet</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>listen</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is your <vocabulary>hearing ability</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>listen</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji>, is someone who listens. This is a <vocabulary>listener</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>listen</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to listen to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hear</vocabulary>.

I <kanji>steal</kanji> by <kanji>listen</kanji>ing to what people say. I do this by <vocabulary>wiretapping</vocabulary> their phone and <vocabulary>bugging</vocabulary> their homes.

盗聴 usually refers to deliberate surveillance using devices like hidden microphones or wiretaps.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Some <kanji>odd</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> are left over here. We don't really understand what happened, because it was a <vocabulary>miracle</vocabulary>, but it certainly left some odd traces behind.

<kanji>Evidence</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> are little bits of <vocabulary>evidence</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>proof</vocabulary>, left behind. They're the <vocabulary>traces</vocabulary> that show that something happened.
All you <kanji>leave behind</kanji> are <kanji>traces</kanji> of the past. These are the <vocabulary>ruins</vocabulary> of what happened before. The <vocabulary>historic remains</vocabulary>...

The kanji means <kanji>dispatch</kanji>, but the word 遣う itself simply means <vocabulary>to use</vocabulary> because it's basically just a more formal version of 使う. Still, the kanji adds a subtle nuance: it suggests you're sending out some care or intention when using something, usually things like time, money, language, or feelings.

Note that you can almost always use 使う in everyday situations. 遣う is usually found in formal or literary Japanese, including older writing styles or texts that aim for a polished or dignified tone.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fight</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to fight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to struggle</vocabulary>.

When you use 闘う instead of 戦う, it often means fighting with strong will or emotion — like battling illness, hardship, or standing up for a cause. It can be used for physical battles too, but it usually implies there's struggle and fighting spirit behind it.
A <kanji>war</kanji> <kanji>fight</kanji> isn't just any old fight — it's a <vocabulary>battle</vocabulary>.

You have <kanji>fight</kanji> in you, and you have the <kanji>intention</kanji> to win. You have <vocabulary>fighting spirit</vocabulary>. Right? Right?! Show me your fighting spirit!

闘志 is a relatively formal word that you'll often see in writing about sports, business, or personal challenges.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

In historical contexts, 陣 refers to an <vocabulary>army camp</vocabulary> or to the <vocabulary>formation</vocabulary>s soldiers used on the battlefield, often in relation to samurai battles. Sometimes, it can even mean the <vocabulary>battle</vocabulary> itself when you see it in the battle's name.

In modern Japanese, that older sense lives on in sports, where 陣 can mean one team's side of the field. More commonly, though, 陣 is used as a suffix for a <vocabulary>group</vocabulary> of people with a shared affiliation, like 報道陣 (press corps) or 教授陣 (faculty).

This <kanji>army camp</kanji> is really well <kanji>manage</kanji>d. Sure, it's still an <vocabulary>army camp</vocabulary>, but it's a really darn good one!

陣 and 陣営 both mean "army camp" when used literally, but in modern Japanese 陣営 is also often used to refer to competing <vocabulary>camp</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>faction</vocabulary>s in politics, business, or sports.
A <kanji>fragrance</kanji> of <kanji>water</kanji> is a <vocabulary>perfume</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>omen</kanji> for the <kanji>climate</kanji> of things is a <vocabulary>sign</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>indication</vocabulary> of change. If there's an omen, there's going to be a sign as well.

A <kanji>before</kanji> <kanji>omen</kanji> is something that tells you about something that will happen before it happens. Really this is just an <vocabulary>omen</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sign</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>look to</kanji> something, you are facing it, taking it head on. That's why this verb vocab is <vocabulary>to face</vocabulary>, as in "to face terrorism," etc.
If you <kanji>look to</kanji> the <kanji>sea</kanji>, you are <vocabulary>seaside</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>coastal</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>look to</kanji> the <kanji>time</kanji>, because something <vocabulary>irregular</vocabulary> seems to be happening outside the normal schedule.

臨時 highlights something out of the ordinary, like 臨時の仕事 (<vocabulary>temporary</vocabulary> job) or 臨時休業 (<vocabulary>unscheduled</vocabulary> closure). It can also sometimes mean "extra," but only in a special, irregular sense, like 臨時ボーナス (extra bonus).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>whittle down</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to whittle something down</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to shave something down</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to reduce something</vocabulary>.

This verb is transitive, meaning you're whittling something down, like a piece of wood, or reducing something, like your expenses.
<kanji>Whittle down</kanji> and <kanji>exclude</kanji> this item from the list. Time to remove it. It's <vocabulary>deletion</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Whittle down</kanji> and <kanji>decrease</kanji> something. This is a <vocabulary>reduction</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cutback</vocabulary>, since you're whittling down and decreasing it.
I <kanji>pledge</kanji> and <kanji>promise</kanji> to do that thing... so much so, I'm willing to sign a <vocabulary>contract</vocabulary> about it.
I <kanji>pledge</kanji> myself to the <kanji>machine</kanji>s. It is my only <vocabulary>chance</vocabulary> to survive the upcoming machine apocalypse.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>favor</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to do a favor</vocabulary> for.
You are <kanji>favor</kanji>ed with <kanji>know</kanji>ing things. You have <vocabulary>wisdom</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intelligence</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hug</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to embrace</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hold</vocabulary> (in one's arms, that is). It can also mean <vocabulary>to hug</vocabulary>, especially in the form of 抱きしめる.

Keep in mind that depending on the context, 抱く can be a euphemism for something way more sexual than just hugging. Not always, of course, but pretty often, so just be careful how you use it! 抱きしめる is the better option if you're talking about regular old hugs.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>display</kanji>, so if you're doing the action of displaying something, you're going <vocabulary>to put up</vocabulary> something, or, sometimes more specifically, <vocabulary>to put up a sign</vocabulary>.
To <kanji>display</kanji> and <kanji>indicate</kanji> something is to put up a <vocabulary>notice</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bulletin</vocabulary>.

To <kanji>display</kanji> your writing so it's <kanji>put on</kanji> public record, it needs to go into <vocabulary>publication</vocabulary>. You're getting it <vocabulary>print</vocabulary>ed in a magazine, newspaper, etc., and this can refer to Internet publications as well.
Your <kanji>aim</kanji> is your <vocabulary>aim</vocabulary>. What are you aiming for? Despite looking like an adjective, this is a noun, so be careful!

If you have to <kanji>aim</kanji> with your <kanji>attack</kanji>, you're probably <vocabulary>shooting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sniping</vocabulary> something with a projectile (like a gun, or something).
A <kanji>burial</kanji> <kanji>ceremony</kanji> is a <vocabulary>funeral</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>burial</kanji>, so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to bury</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to inter</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>burial</kanji> is when you burn the body. You call this <vocabulary>cremation</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>sect</kanji> of <kanji>dispatch</kanji> helps with all the <vocabulary>dispatch</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>deployment</vocabulary> duties.

When used together with the word 社員, this word can also mean <vocabulary>temporary</vocabulary>, in the sense of a temporary employee, possibly someone working for a company via a temping agency.

A <kanji>warm</kanji> <kanji>bed</kanji> is a "<vocabulary>hotbed</vocabulary>."

While "hotbed" can sometimes have positive connotations in English, 温床 generally refers to a <vocabulary>breeding ground</vocabulary> for something unwelcome.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

In Japanese, <kanji>pickle</kanji>d <kanji>thing</kanji>s refer to  <vocabulary>Japanese pickled vegetables</vocabulary>!

漬物 refers to <vocabulary>Japanese pickles</vocabulary> made by soaking vegetables like cucumbers, daikon radish, or eggplant in a solution containing ingredients like salt, rice bran paste, vinegar, and soy sauce. They're left to ferment or marinate, enhancing their flavors. In contrast, western pickles are simply called ピクルス.

If you want the <kanji>power</kanji> to stop a <kanji>bullet</kanji> you need to have just the right amount of <vocabulary>elasticity</vocabulary>. Bullets go right through rigid things, but if the material is strong and has the right amount of <vocabulary>flexibility</vocabulary>, the bullet will bounce right off!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
<kanji>Skewer</kanji>s you grill (焼く) turn into <vocabulary>grilled skewers</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. This also includes the place where your <vocabulary>eyebrows</vocabulary> live: your <vocabulary>brow</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>eyebrows</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is that place between your eyebrows called the <vocabulary>brow</vocabulary>. The technical term for this interval between your brows is the <vocabulary>glabella</vocabulary>, but I bet you never use that word. Unless you're... an eyebrow doctor?

You know that the kanji means <kanji>hug</kanji> and the verb 抱く means "to hug". This noun is similar, but it usually means carrying by hugging, so <vocabulary>holding in one's arms</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>carrying</vocabulary>. This is one that children use a lot!
The kanji means <kanji>saliva</kanji>, and this is the basic, everyday word for that: <vocabulary>spit</vocabulary>.
